title: 109_hr6116
content: The Act may be cited as the "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" and focuses on enhancing Border Patrol agents. The "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to submit a plan within six months to improve recruitment and retention of Border Patrol agents. The plan must include strategies for recruitment and utilization of recruitment authority. The plan mandated by the "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" includes strategies for recruiting and retaining well-qualified Border Patrol agents, assessing the impact of current pay levels on recruitment and retention, and evaluating the potential benefits of increased flexibility in transferring agents between duty stations. SEC. 3. Recruitment and retention bonuses for Border Patrol agents enhancement. Sec. 9702 of title 5, United States Code, allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to pay recruitment bonuses to Border Patrol agents to meet staffing needs. The bonus amount is determined by the Secretary and cannot exceed 25 percent of the annual rate of basic pay. Payment of a bonus under this subsection is in the form of a lump-sum and requires a written service agreement with the United States Border Patrol, specifying the service period and conditions for termination. The section outlines restrictions on paying bonuses for certain positions appointed by the President or in the Senior Executive Service. The authority to pay bonuses will end five years after enactment. Additionally, retention bonuses for Border Patrol Agents are discussed. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay a retention bonus to Border Patrol agents under certain conditions, including entering into a service agreement to complete a specified period of service in exchange for the bonus. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to grant retention bonuses to Border Patrol agents. The bonus amount is determined by the Secretary and cannot exceed 25% of the annual rate of basic pay. The bonus is paid as a lump-sum and is not considered part of basic pay. There is a limitation that the bonus cannot be based on the same period of service as a recruitment bonus. The authority to grant bonuses expires five years after the enactment of the section. The Secretary of Homeland Security may appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol to address challenges faced by the agency. Appointed annuitants are not subject to certain provisions and are not considered employees for retirement purposes. The authority to appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol will terminate five years after enactment. Appointed annuitants are excluded from certain provisions after five years of service and any service performed after ten years from enactment. The term 'annuitant' is defined as per section 8331 or 8401. The authority to appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol will terminate after five years of enactment. Appointed annuitants are excluded from certain provisions after five years of service and any service performed after ten years from enactment. The term 'annuitant' is defined as per section 8331 or 8401. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents for chapter 97 of title 5, United States Code. Border Patrol agent enhancement.
